topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a33a7d63687240090001c3#post_55a33a7d63687240090001c3
No. Not at all.

If tubeheroes and the still rising subscriber counts, is anything to go by, its still going strong.

IF anything it's solidified. The popular and marketable have stayed. The failed ones have melted away into obscurity.
topics.author: 500757fd7f123b75a90003b1

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a33a7d63687240090001c3#post_55a33a7d63687240090001c3
If I had to guess, it's the same phenomenon as when someone says they want to write a novel- they go in without any idea of just how much work has to go into making videos (buying the right equipment, editing footage, and the like). Add some outside, real-world responsibilities into the mix, and it's not hard to see why all but the most dedicated end up just dropping it altogether.

topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a33b4963687253ad0006e0#post_55a33b4963687253ad0006e0
Well yeah; the AAA have solidified, but the C rank or lower just kind of are losing steam.

Markiplier, bestfriends and that are really successful, but only a couple hundred letsplayers are actually able to keep it as a job; everybody else has to keep their actual job.

In order for you to be a financially successful letsplayer you have to make 100k views a day everyday just to earn more than you would be earning on minimum wage.  A lot of letsplayers can't do that.


I don't think letsplayers will go away, rather chances are people that do it as a hobby and not as a job will become the norm.


To use an analogy if you want to make internet comics as a hobby by all means go for it, but if you want to make internet comics as a job I have some bad news to tell you.
